title.narrative: Child labour prevention in the coffee value chain in DR Congo

description.narrative: Coffee is traditionally an important source of revenues for rural families in Eastern Congo. The climate, and altitude and soil of Kabare in the South Kivu province are beneficial for coffee production and various coffee cooperatives are active in the collection, processing and marketing of the remarkable Congolese coffee. With family sizes being large and coffee fields being scattered, there is a risk of child labour in the value chain that needs further investigation and measures taken where possible. This Side Up is a social enterprise that imports specialty coffee from various origins and through its partnership with the Dutch NGO Agriterra it has been connected to coffee cooperative RAEK in Eastern Congo. One of the potential and highly probable main root cause is related to the seasonality of the crop: coffee has two seasons a year of which the ‘small season’ is too limited in volumes for the cooperative to open its collection sites and processing stations. This creates a situation in which coffee producing families do the processing at home, where child labour cannot be well monitored. The partners have the intention to address this issue by marketing the small season coffee as a specialty coffee on European markets, creating the economies of scale required for the cooperative to open its facilities during the small season as well. This will bring the subject of child labour to the attention of consumers in Europe, while having a positive impact in Congo where processing can be done in a centralized manner thus preventing child labour to occur. It is expected that the local impact study will clarify additional/complimentary causes of child labour for which the consortium will identify suitable remediation measures during the project.
